Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Long-Term Dynamics and Resilience of Terrestrial Plant and Animal Communities in the Bahamas

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Extremely well-preserved plant and animal fossils from flooded limestone caves or "blue holes" in the Bahamas provide unparalleled evidence of environmental change over the past five or more millennia. A diverse assemblage of fossil plants, invertebrates, and vertebrates recovered recently from blue holes on the island of Abaco reveals a unique prehistoric terrestrial ecosystem with tortoises as the top herbivores and crocodiles as the dominant predators (rather than mammals, as on continents). This research project will examine long-term ecological change on the islands of Abaco and Eleuthera in order to assess how prehistoric and contemporary plant and animal communities responded to long-term environmental fluctuations, including cultural impacts following the arrival of humans about 1,000 years ago. This project is motivated by two broad, related sets of research questions. First, what were the relative influences of climatic changes vs. human influences in this well-controlled island research setting, and how does this study offer methodological and interpretive insights for distinguishing between these causes in ecological studies elsewhere? Coordinated, multidisciplinary reconstructions of long-term environmental change will consider whether terrestrial ecosystems in the northern Bahamas were resilient in the face of climatic fluctuations but experienced profound impacts with cascading effects following the prehistoric arrival of humans. Dated records of charcoal, pollen, spores, plant macrofossils, and animal fossils will indicate rates of biotic change both before and after human arrival. The second motivating question is: What are the impacts of modern land use on terrestrial biotic communities? The composition and distribution of existing plant and animal communities will be assessed, because they reflect altered resilience as a legacy of both prehistoric and historic land use. The interpretation of long-term trajectories of ecological change on Abaco and Eleuthera will facilitate the differentiation of the biotic effects of climate change vs. the combination of climate change and human impacts in the Bahamas, with larger implications for separating these causes elsewhere around the globe.

This project will provide a basis for predicting the responses of Bahamian and other island ecosystems to climatic and human-related perturbations. In particular, the assessment and management of worldwide biodiversity loss depend on an improved understanding of the dynamics of ecosystems at local and regional geographical scales as well as short and long time frames. Analyses of Bahamian terrestrial ecosystems will provide insights into changing resilience, biodiversity, and ecosystem function resulting from a suite of disturbance regimes, including extreme climatic events, hurricanes, fire, and land-use change. Through a broad network of public and private collaboration in the Bahamas, this project will enhance international scientific collaboration and develop a rigorous program of formal and informal science education, including internships for university students, public field trips and lectures, participation by citizen scientists, and development of educational brochures. The project also will generate an approach to conservation planning and land management grounded in biogeographic and ecological history and prehistory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: We studied both prehistoric and contemporary plant and animal communities in The Bahamas, where recently discovered, extremely well-preserved plant and animal fossils have provided unparalleled evidence of terrestrial environmental change over the past 10 or more millennia. Over 5000 fossils were recovered by scuba divers from a single site, Sawmill Sink on the island of Abaco, from which we identified 96 vertebrate taxa (13 fishes, 11 reptiles, 63 birds, 9 mammals) in the late Pleistocene (ice age) “Owl Roost” bone deposits. We are beginning a new era in the historical biogeography of the West Indies, where we can track changes in species composition through time with unprecedented accuracy and precision. The dramatic global warming and sea level rise that took place at the end of the last ice age from 18,000 to 9000 years ago probably led to the loss of at least 17 species of birds on Abaco. A large and diverse group of 23 reptiles, birds, and mammals persisted through these major environmental changes but then did not survive the last millennium of human activity. Prehistoric humans had profound impacts, with cascading effects on biotic communities, since their arrival one thousand years ago.

Our studies also have shown that contemporary Bahamian dry forests share previously undocumented similarity with tropical dry forests found throughout the Caribbean, although they lack the extensive novel dry forests dominated by non-native, invasive trees found in the Greater Antilles that have established following land use change. Bahamian forests are therefore particularly important regional conservation targets for native flora. These forests also provide very important winter habitat for migratory birds that breed in North America.  Our surveys of living vertebrates further reveal that the Bahamian herpetofauna (amphibians and reptiles) now features a growing number of species and populations of non-native species. Documenting the potential effects of invasive species on native species will be a fertile ground for future research.

Broader Impacts: Our research underscores that conservation planning aimed at mitigating future global change impacts must consider not only direct climate change but also sea level rise and other global change factors – land use change, invasive species, and altered fire regimes. Our project also contributed to science-technology-math-engineering (STEM) education by providing hands-on training in important field and laboratory techniques in the natural sciences to a number of U.S. students and Bahamian collaborators. These techniques range from collecting vegetation data and conducting computer-based modeling to excavating and identifying fossils. Our program of community engagement, building understanding of long-term environmental change, and employing formal and informal education over a sustained period, is a model of scientific outreach in support of evidence-based environmental stewardship. Abaco Blue Holes National Park was established in late 2015 partly as a result of the scientific value of the prehistoric and modern plants and animals of this area, as demonstrated by this research project.
